All Implemented Interfaces:
GraphWithEditableElements<V,E>, SelectionListenableGraph<V,E>, ViewableGraph<V,E>, GraphPropertyListenableGraph<V,E>, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.EventListener, org.jgraph.event.GraphSelectionListener, org.jgrapht.DirectedGraph<V,E>, org.jgrapht.Graph<V,E>, org.jgrapht.ListenableGraph<V,E>
public class DirectedGraph<V extends DefaultListenableVertex,E extends org.jgrapht.graph.DefaultEdge>
extends GraphPropertyListenableDirectedGraph<V,E>
implements GraphWithEditableElements<V,E>

This class is a template for directed graphs in GrALoG. Since it is typed you can specify vertex and edge-classes at construction time. It is also possible to choose among three different flavours of directed graph at construction time namely:

  • SIMPLE_GRAPH - this is a graph without multiple edges or loops
  • MULTI_GRAPH - this is a graph without loops but with multiple edges
  • PSEUDO_GRAPH - this is a graph with both loops and multiple edges

The only reason to subclass this class is that you need to store some information with your graph - which should not be stored with each vertex or edge. In this case you have to override isGraphEditable() to return true. If isGraphEditable() returns true GrALoG looks for all properties defined by your graph ( which follow the JavaBean-Specification ) and makes them editable. Here is a simple example for this: 

 public class MyDirectedGraph extends DirectedGraph {
 
                private int counter;            
 
                public MyDirectedGraph() {
                }
 
                public int getCounter() {
                        return counter;
                }
 
                public void setCounter( int counter ) {
                        int oldValue = this.counter;
                        this.counter = counter;
                        fireGraphPropertyChange( this, new PropertyChangeEvent( this, "counter", oldValue, counter );
                }
 
                public boolean isGraphEditable() {
                        return true;
                }
 }

Notice that in order to allow GrALoG to listen to changes made to your graph you have to fire a PropertyChangeEvent each time a property is changed ( you should use DefaultGraphPropertyListenableGraph.fireGraphPropertyChange(Object, PropertyChangeEvent) to do this ). Note that you also have to define a BeanInfo for your graph - that has to be a class with the same name as your graph suffixed with BeanInfo which should look like this: 

 public class MyDirectedGraphBeanInfo extends SimpleBeanInfo {
        private static final PropertyDescriptor[] PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS = new PropertyDescriptor[1];
        
        static {
                try {
                        PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0] = new PropertyDescriptor( "counter", MyDirectedGraph.class );
                } catch (IntrospectionException e) {
                        // TODO Auto-generated catch block
                        e.printStackTrace();
                }
        }

        public PropertyDescriptor[] getPropertyDescriptors() {
                return PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS;
        }
 }

Note that you can use the PropertyDescriptor to define your own editor for your properties you can also define a customizer for the whole graph ( please refer to JavaBean-Spec if you do not know what a customizer is ). If you want to define properties which are indexed please refer to NestedGraphPropertyBean.

All graphs in GrALoG are jgrapht-classes please refer to JGraphT-Api for information how to use these graphs. There are also some extensions to jgrapht in de.hu.gralog.jgrapht.graph and de.hu.gralog.jgrapht.traverse.

Author:
ordyniak

Method Detail

setTypeInfo

public void setTypeInfo(GraphTypeInfo typeInfo)
Description copied from interface: GraphWithEditableElements
Sets the TypeInfo of this graph. The TypeInfo attribute is required in order to store and load the graph. So if you construct a graph you should always set the TypeInfo of that graph - at a future version this should be moved to the constructor.

Specified by:
setTypeInfo in interface GraphWithEditableElements<V extends DefaultListenableVertex,E extends org.jgrapht.graph.DefaultEdge>

createVertex

public V createVertex()
Description copied from interface: GraphWithEditableElements
Returns a reference to an instance of the vertexclass used by this graph. This method should not return null, since vertices of all graphs should be editable.
